Den (Puṣpa)varga habe ich geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: Wie [es] das Verlangen der Bienen [ist], Blumen zu riechen, [so] möchte[n] mir stärker als das Wunsch [und] Neigung zu allen Tugenden entstehen.

The (Puṣpa)varga I have written [wishing]: As [it is] the desire of the bees to smell flowers, [just so] may, more strongly than that, the wish [for and] the inclination [towards] all virtues arise in me!

all the beings become decorated with the (pure smell of the good conduct [= śīla]) through this deed! May I understand the body [as being] fragile, somewhat like a pot, and may (I) not cling [to it]! 25. Through
(the writing) of the Aśvavarga may I tame the fierce horses of the sense functions! May (I) myself always in (all births) be provided with the force of patience!
Durch das (Schreib)en des Aśvavarga möchte ich die wilden Āyatana-Pferde bändigen.
By (writ)ing the Aśvavarga, may I subdue the wild Āyatana-horses.
May I obtain the chariot driver of the wisdom, the excellent one, may he tame me accurately, [being] resolute in the Law, harnessed far away from the sensual spheres ... 26.

Den (Krodhavava)rga habe ich geschrieben. Durch die Frucht dieser Tat möge mir dieser Wunsch zustande kommen: Solange ich mich auch im Saṃsāra befinden sollte, möchte nicht die Trübung Zorn mich betreffend(?) gesehen werden; [und] (wenn auch) selbst Gemeine mir die (harten) Schwerter (der Worte) regnen lassen sollten, [so] möge mir das Herz [als] der Brustschmuck der Geduld fest sein, ehrerbietig gegen jeder[mann].

The (Krodhava)rga I have written. Through the fruit of this deed, may this wish be granted for me: as long as ever I may find myself in the saṃsāra, may the defilement of wrath not be seen in my case(?); [and] (even when) even miserly ones should let rain the (hard) swords (of speech) [over] me, may my heart, [as] the pectoral of patience, be steadfast, respectful towards every[body].
I have written the Krodhavarga. As the fruit of this deed, may this wish be fulfilled: As long as I would turn in the Saṃsāra, may the anger [and] the passion not see me as [being] enraged. (Even if)
(Den Krodhava)rga habe ich geschrieben: Durch die Frucht d[ies]er Tat möge mir dieser Wunsch in Erfüllung gehen: ...
(The Krodhava)rga I have written. As the fruit of [this] deed, this wish may be fulfilled for me: ...

they let rain really [as mean] as villains the swords of (harsh words), may my heart remain firm, [being] this pectoral ornament of patience, [and] respectful to everybody. 27. (I have written the) Tathāgatav(arga:) May I come together
(with wise ones) through this deed! When these ones will beat the drum of the Law, roaring the four truths, may (I) obtain (to hear) from the mouth of the omniscients in person
the (eight)fold noble path! May this wheel of the Law which has been turned by the king of rṣis remain for long! 28. (I have) written the Śrutavarga, (the excellent one)

(in order to hear) the Law consisting of eighty thousand parts. May I seize [it] at the first lecture [lit. hearing] [and] may I teach [it] to others without flaw (?) while going into mission. May I understand clearly
the internal (senses) [and] the (external obj)ects, may I take the thing belonging to my own as [meaningless as] mere sound [and] may I not cling [to it]. 29. I have written the Ātmavarga: (May I)
Möchte ich meine eigenen Dinge nur als Wort erfassen [und] nicht [daran] haften!
May I take my own things only as a word [and] not cling [to them]!
(be able to ta)me (myself) in all (bi)rths, always desirous of the speaking of these ones, having evoked the inclination to be close to the good ones! (In) sharing ...
Nach dem Wort [wtl. Sagen] derer stets verlangend, möcht ich die Neigung, bei Guten [wtl. zu den Guten hin] zu sein, hervorrufen.
Always yearning for the speech of these, may I evoke the inclination to be with good ones [lit. towards the good].

p.note: The parallel fragments a 1 and b 3 both have the expected form ynauṣkak instead of ynauṣak. In general, this mansucript has more recent spellings and bears traces of late and erouneous forms, while the other two are written in standard orthography. Note further that b 3 has an allative kärtsauñeś.
krentaunaṃś is not a correct form, which would be krentaunaś(c); it seems that the scribe has extended the mark of oblique plural to the plurale tantum.

The reading toko is warranted, but it must be due to a writing error for tākoṃ; the scribe apparently has copied the vowel ‹o› of the neighboring akṣaras and in addition forgot the anusvāra (as he did in the following line). This is another confirmation for copying from mansucripts instead of oral dictation.
karsoym (a3) and källoym (a5) have double virāma writing of the akālk-type.
As for the last colon, the reading is uncertain, we may have ṣ/pal(·)e (·)it/ke; since the metaphor is unclear (and may come from hippology), any restoration would be speculative.

emañña seems to be an adverb, according to the second attestation in b 6; accordingly, ñiś ought to be the direct object of lkoyentär. Judging from the context it should refer to the state of rage or folly resulting from passions, esp. anger.
The parallel b 4 has the reading newent ce, which is more correct.
The grammatically incorrect restoration eneṅkāññ(eṃ) is warranted by the parallel a2. It is most likely due to a copyist error. See the commentary there.
The parallel text a 3 has a slightly different wording; in this version the demonstrative ceṃts refers to the good ones (= krentäṃ) which are mentioned in the next colon.

Here we have rmamñe eru – the parallel text a 3-a4 confirms this – instead of rmamñ= erīmar with regular sandhi in the parallel text b1. As a matter of fact, rmamñ= erīmar is more consistent with the repetitive use of optative forms in this text and it shows regular sandhi. Since the sequence with hiatus is odd for a metrical passage, one would assume that rmamñ= erīmar is more original.
